items.q: How many continents are there on Earth?
items.explanation: The seven continents are Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia/Oceania, Europe, North America, and South America.

items.q: Greenland is the largest non-continental island in the world.
items.explanation: While massive, Greenland is politically an autonomous territory of Denmark and geographically part of North America.

items.q: Mexico City is located in South America.
items.explanation: Mexico City, the capital of Mexico, is located in North America.

items.q: What famous monument is located in Paris, France?
items.explanation: It was completed in 1889 as the entrance arch to the 1889 World's Fair.

items.q: Which ocean borders the west coast of the United States?
items.explanation: States like California, Oregon, and Washington have coastlines along the Pacific.

items.q: What is the capital of the United Kingdom?
items.explanation: London sits on the River Thames and is famous for landmarks like Big Ben and Buckingham Palace.

items.q: Name the imaginary line that runs horizontally around the middle of the Earth.
items.explanation: Places near the equator generally experience hot, tropical climates all year round.

items.q: What two colors are on Canada's national flag?
items.explanation: It features a distinct red maple leaf in its center.

items.q: What do we call a giant body of slow-moving ice?
items.explanation: Glaciers move extremely slowly, carving and reshaping the landscape as they go.

items.q: What is the largest hot desert in the world, stretching across much of North Africa?
items.explanation: It is comparable in size to the entire land area of the United States.
